question: A 30
sols_html:
The normal of the plane is given by,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{n}=\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w}\end{aligned}\]

and therefore if a vector is in the plane it must be orthogonal to this normal vector. Recall that vectors are orthogonal if the scalar (dot) product is zero. Therefore we seek to check if,

\[\begin{aligned} (\mathbf{v}\times(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w}))\cdot(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w})=(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{n})\cdot\mathbf{n}=0.\end{aligned}\]

To do this we use the triple scalar triple product which for any three vectors a, b, and c states,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{a}\cdot(\mathbf{b}\times\mathbf{c})=\mathbf{c}\cdot(\mathbf{a}\times\mathbf{b})=\mathbf{b}\cdot(\mathbf{c}\times\mathbf{a}).\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we see that,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{n}\cdot(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{n})=\mathbf{v}\cdot(\mathbf{n}\times\mathbf{n})=0\end{aligned}\]

by the virtue that parallel vectors have a zero cross-product. Therefore we see that the vector \(\mathbf{v}\times(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w})\) is orthogonal to the normal vector of the plane and thus lies in the plane itself. Therefore, the statement is true.

From hint 2, we recall that since the plane is in \(\mathbb{R}^2\), the two linearly independent vectors inside are enough to span the entire space. Therefore, any vector, y, inside P can be written as a linearly dependent combination of v and w,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}=d_1\mathbf{v}+d_2\mathbf{w}\end{aligned}\]

for some scalars, \(d_1\) and \(d_2\). Recall that for any vectors, a, b, and c, we can define the vector triple product as

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{a}\times(\mathbf{b}\times\mathbf{c})=(\mathbf{a}\cdot\mathbf{c})\mathbf{b}-(\mathbf{a}\cdot\mathbf{b})\mathbf{c}.\end{aligned}\]

We wish to see if the vector \(\mathbf{v}\times(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w})\) is inside the plane P. Using the vector triple product,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}\times(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w})=(\mathbf{v}\cdot\mathbf{w})\mathbf{v}-(\mathbf{v}\cdot\mathbf{v})\mathbf{w}.\end{aligned}\]

But this is a linear combination of the vectors \(\mathbf{v}\) and \(\mathbf{w}\), and hence is inside the plane P. To see this more clearly, define

\[\begin{aligned} d_1&=(\mathbf{v}\cdot\mathbf{w})\\ d_2&=-(\mathbf{v}\cdot\mathbf{v})\end{aligned}\]

then we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}\times(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w})=d_1\mathbf{v}+d_2\mathbf{w}\end{aligned}\]

and therefore the vector \(\mathbf{v}\times(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w})\) is inside the plane P, making the statement true.
